Challenges and Considerations
-----------------------------

While artificial intelligence is transforming healthcare with faster diagnoses, personalized treatments and automated workflows, its adoption comes with significant challenges. AI-driven healthcare solutions must navigate ethical concerns, regulatory complexities, data quality issues and high implementation costs. Addressing these challenges is essential to ensure that AI contributes positively to patient care while maintaining trust, fairness and long-term sustainability.

### Ethical and Regulatory Concerns

AI in healthcare operates at the intersection of innovation and patient safety, making ethical and regulatory compliance a top priority. One of the most pressing concerns is patient data privacy. AI systems rely on vast amounts of medical data to train and improve their accuracy, but this raises concerns about how patient information is stored, shared and protected. Hospitals and AI developers must balance the need for data-driven insights with strict privacy laws like HIPAA (Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act) in the U.S. and GDPR (General Data Protection Regulation) in Europe. Failure to comply with these regulations can lead to legal issues and loss of patient trust.

Beyond privacy, AI-driven medical tools must meet rigorous safety and effectiveness standards before being deployed. Regulatory bodies like the FDA (Food and Drug Administration) and EMA (European Medicines Agency) are increasingly scrutinizing AI-powered medical devices, requiring clinical validation to prove their reliability. Getting AI systems certified is a complex, time-consuming process and ensuring ongoing compliance adds another layer of difficulty.

Additionally, there are ethical concerns surrounding AI’s decision-making in healthcare. AI models can recommend diagnoses or treatment plans, but the final responsibility lies with medical professionals. Over-reliance on AI without human oversight could lead to errors, raising the question of accountability — who is responsible when AI makes a mistake? Healthcare institutions must ensure that AI tools assist, rather than replace, human expertise and that clear guidelines are in place to govern AI-assisted decisions.

It’s been more than two years since ChatGPT was first released, and during that time artificial intelligence has become synonymous with generative AI. When most people discuss AI, they’re usually referring to [large language models](https://healthtechmagazine.net/article/2024/07/future-llms-in-healthcare-clinical-use-cases-perfcon) (LLMs) and [related chatbots](https://healthtechmagazine.net/article/2024/08/5-questions-about-chatbots-improve-patient-experience). That’s how big of an impact generative AI had across industries — as well as everyday people around the world — and healthcare is no exception.

For many healthcare organizations, AI is still a buzz phrase, but one that is attractive due to its promise to improve clinical and administrative workflows. In 2024, early adopters showcased its possibilities. This year, we expect to see more organizations dipping their toes into the generative AI space. While more healthcare leaders are considering and [preparing for AI implementation](https://www.cdw.com/content/cdw/en/solutions/artificial-intelligence-ai.html), they are also pushing vendors to show the actual value their solutions provide.

In 2025, we expect healthcare organizations to have more risk tolerance for AI initiatives, which will lead to increased adoption. However, they will also be intentional about using solutions that meet a business need and bring ROI in terms of increased efficiency or cost savings.

Here are some of the ways healthcare organizations are likely to approach AI in 2025.

Which AI Solutions Will Healthcare Organizations Adopt in 2025?
---------------------------------------------------------------

Healthcare leaders are interested in AI tools that provide clear value, whether that’s a better clinician experience, reduced costs, increased administrative efficiencies or improved patient care. Here are some examples.

### Ambient Listening Reduces Clinical Documentation

Many organizations are already going down the AI path with [ambient listening](https://healthtechmagazine.net/article/2024/08/ambient-listening-in-healthcare-perfcon), which are machine learning-powered audio solutions. Used by physicians initially before being expanded to nurses, the voice-recognition technology listens to and analyzes patient-provider conversations in real time, then extracts the relevant information for use in clinical notes, meeting billing and coding requirements. This enables clinicians to focus on the patient rather than having to multitask to complete documentation.

A major reason that [organizations are choosing ambient listening](https://www.cdw.com/content/cdw/en/articles/dataanalytics/transformative-benefits-ambient-listening-in-healthcare.html) as a first step into AI is that they’ve evaluated and found clear ROI around these solutions when it comes to clinical efficiency and mitigating burnout.

Another reason is that ambient listening isn’t considered as risky as it was in the past. It now falls into a category of low-hanging fruit in the healthcare AI space, along with chart summarization.

### Pushing for Increased Accuracy and Transparency in Generative AI

Some healthcare organizations are beginning to experiment with [retrieval-augmented generation](https://www.cdw.com/content/cdw/en/articles/digitalworkspace/3-areas-where-rag-implementation-can-be-improved.html). RAG is an AI framework that combines traditional vector database capabilities with LLMs. In other words, users get the benefits of a generative AI-powered chatbot that can access an organization’s more accurate and recent data.

RAG allows the organization’s chatbot to produce better answers for staff in Q&A applications. This reduces some of the pitfalls of [using generative AI tools](https://healthtechmagazine.net/article/2024/11/chime24-setting-record-straight-generative-ai).

The use of synthetic data in AI development and testing is another area that will see heightened interest, because having decent data to validate models is a challenge. This is part of a larger trend in model testing and model assurance capabilities. Performance claims for these models will face increasing scrutiny by healthcare organizations.

In the past, organizations didn’t know what questions to ask, but now there’s a lot more education available. Healthcare leaders want to ensure that the models do what they promise. Groups such as the [Coalition for Health AI](https://chai.org/) are creating frameworks to do this very thing.

[_**DIVE DEEPER:**Demystify artificial intelligence adoption for your organization._](https://www.cdw.com/content/cdw/en/articles/digitalworkspace/demystifying-artificial-intelligence-adoption-for-your-organization.html)

### **Machine Vision Improves Patient Care**

[Adding cameras, sensors and microphones to patient rooms](https://healthtechmagazine.net/article/2022/08/what-patient-room-next-and-how-can-healthcare-organizations-achieve-it) enables healthcare organizations to collect more data that can be analyzed by AI platforms to improve care. For example, cameras can detect when a patient has turned over in bed, and the platform can alert care team members that they don’t need to turn the patient manually. Some cameras can also detect when a patient is getting up and alert staff so they can prevent a fall.

As these tools advance and more Internet of Medical Things sensors and cameras are [added to patient rooms](https://www.cdw.com/content/cdw/en/articles/services/patient-room-next-the-evolution-of-care.html), more solutions will combine the AI capabilities of machine vision and ambient listening to improve proactive patient care as well as clinical workflows.

Will AI Regulation Increase in 2025?
------------------------------------

There’s already been an uptick in AI regulation, and we expect that to increase due to the nature of AI and fears of the unknown. Whether it comes from the government or from regulatory agencies and organizations, there will likely be new regulation to [ensure AI isn’t used inappropriately](https://healthtechmagazine.net/article/2024/07/considerations-responsible-use-generative-ai-healthcare). However, it’s important to achieve a balance between regulation and innovation.

Healthcare organizations will also become more interested in learning how to comply with existing regulations such as the Office of the National Coordinator for Health Information Technology’s [HTI-1 Final Rule](https://www.healthit.gov/sites/default/files/facas/2024-01-18_HTI-1_Final_Rule_Overview_508.pdf) regarding health data, technology and interoperability.

Preparing for AI Adoption in Healthcare
---------------------------------------

AI provides healthcare organizations with exciting possibilities for provider experience and patient care, but being able to use AI tools effectively comes down to [IT infrastructure](https://healthtechmagazine.net/article/2024/11/how-can-healthcare-organizations-prepare-their-cloud-safely-implement-ai). Have an organization’s speeds and feeds been upgraded to handle these solutions?

Organizations looking to implement AI solutions should also work on getting their data shop in order. Even out-of-the-box, consumable [AI solutions require good data governance](https://www.cdw.com/content/cdw/en/articles/dataanalytics/data-governance-strategies-for-ai-success.html). The more an organization understands its own data, the easier it is for the IT team to know how a solution will work in the organization’s environment. If the data isn’t in order, then AI implementation is going to be more of a challenge.

AI governance is another important factor in achieving implementation success. An organization should have a good definition of what AI is and be able to ensure that the right people exist within the organization to discuss potential risks, ROI and cultural readiness. It’s worth having those discussions early and often to corral the different AI interests inside the organization.

[_**CONSIDER:**When is the cloud right for healthcare organizations deploying AI?_](https://www.cdw.com/content/cdw/en/articles/cloud/when-the-cloud-is-right-for-organizations-deploying-artificial-intelligence.html)

IT leaders also need to [consider how to integrate AI solutions into workflows effectively](https://healthtechmagazine.net/article/2024/10/ai-in-healthcare-how-its-used-future-perfcon) while gaining user buy-in. The solution may be great, but if it’s implemented incorrectly, then you might as well have done nothing at all.

Most healthcare organizations have limited budgets; therefore, some AI tools will make the cut while others won’t. Tools that don’t solve an existing problem or provide some form of return on the money being spent will be a lower priority for an organization, which may choose to do what it’s always done instead.

Once healthcare organizations are ready to move to the next step of AI implementation, it can be helpful to collaborate with a technology partner that has experience in the realm. [CDW](https://www.cdw.com/) offers [data workshops](https://dvs.cdw.com/icx-workshop) to help healthcare organizations prepare their data for AI. We also offer [strategy engagements for modern data platforms](https://www.cdw.com/content/cdw/en/solutions/analytics/modern-data-platform.html) and deploying generative AI.

We can also help executive teams level-set on what AI is and isn’t, and how to approach management. Ultimately, we help guide healthcare organizations to ensure that their AI initiative is sustainable and becomes part of their culture.

Artificial intelligence (AI) is poised to revolutionize the healthcare industry by 2025, bringing transformative changes to patient care, operational efficiencies, and addressing key challenges within the system. Insights from twenty-four healthcare executives provide a comprehensive view of the potential advancements, challenges, and trends likely to emerge. This article delves into the multifaceted impact of AI on healthcare, highlighting key themes and common points from industry leaders.

AI in Care Coordination and Primary Care
----------------------------------------

### Enhancing Care Coordination with AI

Ashley Barrow, Founder and CEO of RE-Assist, emphasizes the role of AI in bolstering care coordination through the T.E.A.M. model. This approach aims to make healthcare delivery smarter and more equitable by integrating AI tools to identify high-risk patients and streamline resource allocation. The model focuses on sustained patient engagement and proactive management of chronic conditions. By leveraging AI, healthcare systems can predict patient needs and deploy resources more effectively. This targeted approach not only enhances the quality of care patients receive but also optimizes operational efficiencies within medical facilities.

Moreover, AI-driven predictive analytics can alert healthcare professionals to potential issues before they escalate, such as recognizing early signs of a relapse in chronic condition patients. By providing timely interventions, AI can significantly reduce hospital readmission rates and improve overall health outcomes. As these AI systems evolve, they will offer increasingly sophisticated insights, enabling healthcare providers to tailor treatments more precisely to individual patient profiles, thus fostering a more personalized and patient-centric approach to healthcare.

### Empowering Nontraditional Providers

AI-driven workflows will empower nontraditional providers, such as community health workers and paramedics, to enhance access to care. By leveraging AI, these providers can deliver more efficient and effective care, particularly in underserved communities. This shift will help bridge gaps in healthcare access and improve overall patient outcomes. For example, AI algorithms can assess patient data in real-time and recommend appropriate interventions or referrals, empowering nontraditional providers to make informed decisions swiftly and accurately.

Additionally, mobile apps and AI-powered tools can facilitate remote monitoring and diagnostics, enabling community health workers to extend their reach and impact. This is particularly beneficial in rural or remote areas where access to healthcare facilities is limited. By integrating AI into the daily practices of these providers, the healthcare system can ensure that more individuals receive timely and appropriate care, thus reducing disparities in health outcomes. This democratization of healthcare resources will play a crucial role in achieving more equitable healthcare delivery by 2025.

Regulatory Considerations
-------------------------

### Navigating Legal and Regulatory Frameworks

Amanda Barefoot, MHA, Managing Director of Health Care & Life Sciences Solutions, warns that while AI aims to alleviate provider burdens, legal and regulatory frameworks could inadvertently increase administrative drains if not carefully crafted. There will be a push towards greater interoperability and data-sharing to strengthen the public health framework. The integration of AI in healthcare necessitates meticulous attention to privacy laws, data protection regulations, and compliance standards to ensure patient confidentiality and ethical use.

Moreover, regulatory bodies will need to develop comprehensive guidelines that address the unique challenges posed by AI technologies, such as algorithmic transparency and accountability. These guidelines should ensure that AI solutions are deployed in a manner that is fair, unbiased, and benefits all patients. As AI’s role in healthcare expands, continuous collaboration between technology developers, healthcare providers, and regulators will be essential to create a cohesive legal framework that supports innovation while safeguarding patient rights.

### Ensuring Compliance and Data Security

As AI becomes more integrated into healthcare, ensuring compliance with regulatory standards and maintaining data security will be paramount. Healthcare organizations will need to navigate complex regulations to protect patient data and ensure the ethical use of AI technologies. Robust cybersecurity measures will be essential to prevent data breaches and unauthorized access to sensitive patient information. This includes implementing advanced encryption techniques, secure data storage solutions, and regular security audits.

Moreover, healthcare providers will need to foster a culture of data privacy and security awareness among their staff. This can be achieved through comprehensive training programs that educate employees about the latest security protocols and best practices for handling patient data. By prioritizing data security and compliance, healthcare organizations can build trust with patients and ensure that AI technologies are used responsibly. This will ultimately contribute to the broader acceptance and successful adoption of AI in healthcare, paving the way for its transformative potential.

Mental and Behavioral Health
----------------------------

### Designing AI for Mental Health

In its deliberate approach to addressing the complexities of cryptocurrencies, the SEC opted for another delay in its verdict on the spot Ethereum ETF.

Dr. Caroline Carney of Magellan Health stresses the importance of designing AI with definitive endpoints and clinical outcomes in mind. Reliable and valid mental health AI solutions must support individuals throughout their mental health journeys, while considering comorbid conditions. This entails developing algorithms that can accurately diagnose mental health disorders, predict potential crises, and recommend personalized treatment plans. Incorporating AI into mental healthcare can enhance early detection and intervention, thus preventing conditions from worsening.

Additionally, AI can facilitate continuous monitoring of patients, providing real-time insights into their mental health status. For example, AI-driven applications can analyze behavioral patterns, social interactions, and physiological data to detect early signs of depression or anxiety. By leveraging these insights, mental health professionals can offer timely support and adjust treatment plans as needed. This proactive approach can significantly improve patient outcomes, ensuring that individuals receive the right care at the right time.

### Supporting Mental Health Journeys

AI can play a crucial role in supporting mental health journeys by providing personalized and timely interventions. By analyzing patient data, AI can identify patterns and predict potential mental health crises, enabling proactive care and support. This includes offering recommendations for coping strategies, connecting patients to support networks, and providing access to digital therapy resources. AI-powered chatbots and virtual assistants can also offer round-the-clock support, helping patients manage their symptoms and access care whenever needed.

Furthermore, AI can enhance the efficiency of mental health professionals by automating routine tasks, such as scheduling appointments and managing patient records. This allows clinicians to focus more on direct patient care and spend less time on administrative duties. By integrating AI into mental health services, healthcare providers can offer a more comprehensive and responsive care experience. This holistic approach not only improves patient satisfaction but also supports long-term mental health management.

AI as an Amplifier of Human Capabilities
----------------------------------------

### Enhancing Clinician Abilities

Joe DeVivo, CEO at Butterfly Network, envisions AI as a force that amplifies human capabilities rather than replacing them. AI will enhance clinicians’ abilities to process data and identify trends, democratizing access to advanced medical technologies like ultrasound imaging. By assisting healthcare professionals in interpreting complex data sets, AI can improve diagnostic accuracy and speed up decision-making processes. This collaboration between human expertise and AI-powered insights can lead to more informed and effective patient care.

Moreover, AI can support clinicians in staying updated with the latest medical research and treatment advancements. By analyzing vast amounts of scientific literature and clinical data, AI can provide clinicians with evidence-based recommendations tailored to individual patient needs. This ensures that patients receive the most current and effective treatments available. The integration of AI into clinical practice empowers healthcare providers to deliver higher-quality care, ultimately improving patient outcomes and overall satisfaction.

### Democratizing Medical Technologies

AI will make advanced medical technologies more accessible to a broader range of healthcare providers. This democratization will improve diagnostic accuracy and patient outcomes, particularly in resource-limited settings. By leveraging AI, healthcare facilities can offer sophisticated diagnostic services, such as imaging and pathology, without the need for expensive equipment or specialized personnel. This can help bridge the gap between urban and rural healthcare, ensuring that all patients have access to high-quality medical care.

Furthermore, AI-driven telemedicine platforms can facilitate remote consultations and diagnostics, enabling patients to receive expert medical advice without having to travel long distances. This is particularly beneficial for individuals living in underserved areas or those with limited mobility. By making advanced medical technologies more widely available, AI can contribute to a more equitable and inclusive healthcare system. This shift has the potential to enhance health outcomes for diverse populations by providing timely and accurate diagnoses, regardless of geographic location.

Decision Augmentation
---------------------

Seeking to enhance the decision-making process, the organization implemented several advanced analytical tools to augment their evaluations. This technology integration aims to provide a more accurate and comprehensive understanding of various scenarios, thereby facilitating more informed and effective decisions.

### Integrating AI into Daily Workflows

Jeff Elton, CEO of ConcertAI, points out that AI will integrate more deeply into daily workflows, augmenting human decisions with context-sensitive solutions and large language models (LLMs). This integration is imperative to meet the growing demand for care amid a shortage of specialists. AI can support clinicians by providing real-time data analysis, suggesting potential diagnoses, and recommending treatment plans based on comprehensive patient data. By seamlessly integrating into existing healthcare systems, AI can enhance efficiency and reduce the cognitive burden on healthcare providers.

Additionally, AI can streamline administrative workflows by automating tasks such as appointment scheduling, billing, and documentation. This allows healthcare professionals to allocate more time to patient care and less to non-clinical duties. The use of AI in daily workflows also promotes consistency and accuracy in clinical practices, leading to better patient outcomes. As AI technology continues to advance, its ability to integrate and augment human decision-making will become increasingly vital in managing the complexities of modern healthcare.

### Context-Sensitive Solutions

AI will provide context-sensitive solutions that enhance decision-making processes in healthcare. By analyzing vast amounts of data, AI can offer insights and recommendations that support clinicians in delivering high-quality care. This includes evaluating patient histories, lab results, imaging studies, and even genetic information to provide a comprehensive view of the patient’s health. With this holistic perspective, healthcare providers can make more informed decisions and tailor treatments to individual patient needs.

Moreover, AI can assist in identifying potential drug interactions, contraindications, and adverse effects, ensuring that prescribed treatments are both safe and effective. This level of precision and personalization in healthcare can lead to improved patient outcomes and reduced incidences of medical errors. As AI continues to evolve, its ability to provide contextually relevant information will be crucial in enhancing clinical decision-making and optimizing patient care.

Validation and Trust in AI
--------------------------

### Building Trust through Validation

Elliott Green, CEO & Co-Founder of Dandelion Health, underscores the need for AI validation and best practices to build trust and address biases. Clear regulatory guidance will be essential to mitigate these concerns and foster broader adoption of AI in healthcare. Rigorous validation processes will ensure that AI algorithms are reliable, accurate, and free from biases that could adversely affect patient care. By establishing and adhering to industry standards, healthcare providers can gain confidence in AI technologies and their potential to improve health outcomes.

Furthermore, transparency in how AI algorithms are developed and implemented is crucial for building trust. Healthcare organizations should actively involve stakeholders, including patients, in the validation process to ensure that AI solutions meet the needs of diverse populations. By fostering an environment of collaboration and openness, the healthcare industry can overcome skepticism and pave the way for widespread AI adoption.

### Addressing Biases in AI

To ensure the ethical use of AI, it is crucial to address biases in AI algorithms. By implementing rigorous validation processes and adhering to best practices, healthcare organizations can build trust in AI technologies and promote their responsible use. This involves regularly testing AI models for biases and making necessary adjustments to ensure they are fair and equitable. Additionally, diverse datasets should be used in training AI algorithms to reflect various patient demographics and conditions accurately.

Moreover, ongoing monitoring and evaluation of AI systems are essential to identify and rectify any emerging biases. Engaging with ethical review boards and regulatory agencies can help establish guidelines for responsible AI usage. By prioritizing fairness and transparency, healthcare organizations can ensure that AI solutions benefit all patients and uphold the highest ethical standards. This commitment to ethical AI practices will be fundamental in gaining public trust and achieving the full potential of AI in healthcare.

Generative AI
-------------

Generative AI refers to a class of artificial intelligence models that are capable of generating new, original content based on the data they have been trained on. This technology can produce various types of media, including text, images, audio, and video, by learning patterns and structures from vast datasets. The applications of generative AI span multiple industries, such as entertainment, design, and marketing, enabling creators to automate content creation, enhance creative workflows, and develop innovative solutions.

### Transformative Potential of Generative AI

Aashima Gupta from Google Cloud highlights the transformative potential of generative AI in creating comprehensive views of patient health, streamlining workflows, and reducing administrative burdens. AI-powered solutions are already making significant strides in healthcare. By synthesizing and analyzing data from various sources, generative AI can provide a holistic understanding of a patient’s health status, leading to more accurate diagnoses and personalized treatment plans. This comprehensive approach allows healthcare providers to address the underlying causes of medical conditions rather than just treating symptoms.

Additionally, generative AI can enhance predictive analytics, enabling healthcare professionals to anticipate potential health issues and intervene before they become critical. This proactive approach can improve patient outcomes and reduce healthcare costs by preventing complications and hospitalizations. As generative AI continues to evolve, its ability to integrate and analyze complex medical data will be instrumental in advancing personalized medicine and preventive care.

### Streamlining Workflows with AI

Generative AI can streamline workflows by automating routine tasks and providing real-time insights. This efficiency will allow healthcare providers to focus more on patient care and less on administrative tasks. By automating processes such as appointment scheduling, billing, and documentation, AI can significantly reduce the administrative burden on healthcare professionals. This not only enhances productivity but also ensures that medical staff can dedicate more time and attention to patient interactions and care delivery.

Furthermore, real-time insights generated by AI can support clinical decision-making and improve care coordination. For example, AI can analyze patient data to identify potential gaps in care and recommend appropriate follow-up actions. This ensures that patients receive continuous and comprehensive care, leading to better health outcomes. By leveraging the capabilities of generative AI, healthcare organizations can optimize their operations and enhance the overall patient experience.

Elderly and Vulnerable Populations
----------------------------------

### Addressing Administrative Burnout

Bharath Kakarla of Intus Care emphasizes the importance of AI in addressing administrative burnout and expanding care beyond traditional settings, particularly for older and vulnerable patients. Robust interoperability will be key to achieving a cohesive healthcare ecosystem. By automating administrative tasks and streamlining workflows, AI can alleviate the burden on healthcare providers, enabling them to focus more on direct patient care. This is especially crucial in settings where resources are limited and the demand for healthcare services is high.

Moreover, AI-driven solutions can enhance care coordination and communication among healthcare providers, caregivers, and family members. This ensures that elderly and vulnerable patients receive consistent and comprehensive care, even when transitioning between different care settings. By reducing administrative burnout and improving care coordination, AI can contribute to better health outcomes and quality of life for these populations.

### Expanding Care Beyond Traditional Settings

AI will enable healthcare providers to deliver care beyond traditional settings, reaching elderly and vulnerable populations more effectively. This expansion will improve access to care and enhance the quality of life for these patients. For example, AI-powered telemedicine platforms can facilitate remote consultations, allowing patients to receive medical advice and treatment from the comfort of their homes. This is particularly beneficial for individuals with mobility issues or those living in remote areas with limited access to healthcare facilities.

Additionally, AI can support remote monitoring and management of chronic conditions, ensuring that patients receive timely interventions and avoid unnecessary hospitalizations. Wearable devices equipped with AI can track vital signs and other health metrics, alerting healthcare providers to any concerning changes in real time. By enabling continuous monitoring and proactive care, AI can help maintain the health and well-being of elderly and vulnerable patients, reducing the need for frequent in-person visits and hospital stays.

Conversational AI and Customer Care Enhancements

Advancements in conversational AI have significantly transformed customer care in various industries. By leveraging sophisticated algorithms and natural language processing, businesses can provide more efficient and personalized support to their customers. This technology not only facilitates quicker response times but also allows for 24/7 customer service, ensuring that customer inquiries and issues can be addressed promptly at any time of day or night. As a result, companies can enhance customer satisfaction, loyalty, and overall experience, positioning themselves more competitively in the market. Furthermore, conversational AI can analyze customer interactions to gather insightful data, enabling businesses to continually refine their strategies and services based on this feedback.

![](https://cdn.prod.website-files.com/662f5a172bc77f3d81c617b2/66ffdc6f64ca6118f13bf292_66ffdc3885fb5c5c1a756a4a_AI%2520in%2520healthcare%2520concerns%2520and%2520risks.png)

## Data privacy and security risks in healthcare

Data is a valuable asset, this is why [EMR](https://www.forbes.com/advisor/business/software/ehr-vs-emr/) (Electronic Medical Records) and EHR (Electronic Health Records) storage and processing have so many regulatory guidelines. Bigger corporations will have their own data to train models with, but when it comes to smaller companies and startups, having access to data (even anonymized) is critical. Â

The industry is yet to learn how to regulate, store, and exchange the data with community clouds being one of the pieces of the puzzle.

### Risks:

#### Unauthorized access and data breaches

The extensive use of sensitive patient data increases the risk of cyberattacks and unauthorized access, potentially leading to identity theft and loss of patient confidentiality.

#### Inadequate data protection measures

Insufficient security protocols can result in accidental data leaks and misuse of personal health information.

### Mitigation strategies:

#### Robust encryption and security protocols

Implementing advanced encryption methods and multi-factor authentication to protect data integrity and confidentiality is already an industry standard that is gaining even more significance now.

#### Compliance with regulatory standards in healthcare (HIPAA, GDPR, CCPA)

Companies need to adhere strictly to regulations such as HIPAA and GDPR, ensuring that all AI systems meet legal requirements for data protection and patient privacy. Â

#### Regular security audits and assessments

While major pharmaceutical companies have rigid internal and external security audits, this continuous audit and monitoring mindset is applicable to smaller players in HealthTech as well. Conducting ongoing evaluations of security systems helps to identify and address vulnerabilities promptly.

#### Data anonymization and de-identification

Due to the highly sensitive nature of health records, this [PII data](https://www.ibm.com/topics/pii) needs to be anonymized as early on the chain as possible, leaving the scientists and developers with pure statistical input. Â

Utilizing techniques to remove personally identifiable information from datasets used in AI training and analysis is expected to be widely used across the board in HealthTech.

## Algorithmic bias and fairness issues

Countries with developed economies tend to have better healthcare systems with plenty of structured and unstructured health records to train models upon. The level of healthcare across different continents can be demonstrated with the life expectancy [statistics](https://www.statista.com/statistics/1302736/global-life-expectancy-by-region-country-historical/) as one of the factors: in LatAm countries people live 75 years on average, in Western Europe â 81, in Asia â 73 years, and in Africa â only 66 years.

States with poor health infrastructure, outdated medical equipment, and poorly digitized public healthcare ecosystems will have little info to share with AI models.

Similarly, some age groups may take their health issues more or less seriously, giving rise to another form of bias when it comes to available data. Â

Even culturally some nations are less prone to visit doctors as their mentality may be more stoic in essence, or more natural-remedy-inclined.

### Risks:

#### Disparities in healthcare outcomes

Biased AI models can perpetuate and even exacerbate existing inequalities in healthcare by providing less accurate or effective services to certain populations.

#### Reduced trust in AI systems

Awareness of biases can lead to skepticism and reluctance among both patients and healthcare providers to adopt AI technologies.

### Mitigation strategies:

#### Diverse and representative datasets Â

Companies need to ensure that training data encompasses a wide range of demographic groups and clinical scenarios to enhance the generalizability and fairness of AI models.

#### Bias detection and correction mechanisms

Research institutions and data scientists working in the healthcare sector should learn to implement methods to identify, quantify, and rectify biases within AI algorithms throughout the development and deployment processes.

#### Transparent model development

In the ideal scenario, the HealthTech industry will learn to maintain transparency in how AI models are developed and make information about data sources and methodologies available to stakeholders.

#### Inclusive stakeholder engagement Â

Another way to prevent bias is to involve diverse groups, including clinicians, patients, and ethicists, in the design and evaluation of AI systems, - to ensure that multiple perspectives are considered.

## Over-reliance on AI and reduced human oversight

As humanity witnesses more instances of successful AI implementation, companies may grow to rely on Artificial Intelligence more, creating potential caveats for errors and oversights to slip into the process and outcomes.

In the medical field, human supervision is critical due to the cost of the mistake and the fact, that diagnostics and treatment are so complex and have many unique variables.

### Risks:

#### Diagnostic and treatment errors Â

Excessive dependence on AI recommendations without adequate human judgment can lead to errors, especially in complex or atypical cases.

#### Erosion of clinical skills

Reliance on automated systems may diminish healthcare professionals' expertise and decision-making abilities over time.

### Mitigation strategies:

#### Maintaining human-in-the-loop systems

To mitigate the over-reliance on AI in Healthcare companies will need to design AI applications to support rather than replace human clinicians, ensuring that final decisions involve human oversight and expertise.

#### Comprehensive training and education Â

Training for healthcare professionals on effectively integrating AI tools into their practice is going to be a pivotal component to maintain critical thinking and clinical judgment.

#### Establishing clear accountability frameworks

CAIOs of medical institutions need to focus on defining roles and responsibilities clearly, ensuring that accountability for patient outcomes remains with qualified healthcare providers.

## Regulatory and legal challenges related to the use of AIÂ in healthcare

Governmental and commercial institutions alike have their stance on AI in its early formative stages. Humanity will see more regulations and governance in terms of Artificial Intelligence, specifically in such a high-litigation industry as healthcare.

One such Pan-American initiative is a [Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights](https://www.whitehouse.gov/ostp/ai-bill-of-rights/).

Below we set out the most eminent risks in legal perspective and ways to minimize negative effects.

### Risks:

#### Lack of standardization

Inconsistent regulations and standards across regions can create confusion and hinder the widespread adoption of AI in healthcare.

#### Liability concerns Â

Determining legal responsibility for errors made by AI systems can be complex, potentially leading to litigation and financial risks.

### Mitigation strategies:

#### Developing comprehensive regulatory frameworks

One of the key short-term missions of the industry is to develop a fair playing field for all institutions. Authorities and businesses need to collaborate with policymakers, industry leaders, and regulatory bodies to establish clear and consistent guidelines for AI in healthcare.

#### Ongoing policy adaptation

It is critical that policymakers update regulations continuously to keep pace with rapid technological advancements and emerging ethical considerations. Â

#### Insurance and liability coverage

Another focal point is with the insurance industry, which will need to develop appropriate insurance models and legal agreements that address liability issues related to AI usage in clinical settings. Â

Just like any other major pharmaceutical company, Astra Zeneca has several digital optimization initiatives in scientific and administrative departments. For example, they use Gen AI to improve the efficiency of their regulatory submissions. Â

## Technical limitations and reliability issues

As a maturing technology, AI-powered systems have many technical inconsistencies and errors to overcome.

### Risks: Â

#### System failures and errors

Technical glitches, inaccuracies, or system downtimes can disrupt healthcare services and compromise patient safety.

#### Interoperability challenges

Difficulties in integrating AI systems with existing healthcare infrastructure can limit their effectiveness and utility.

### Mitigation strategies:

#### Rigorous testing and validation

The first way to lower any technical risks is by conducting extensive testing under diverse conditions to ensure the reliability and accuracy of AI systems before deployment.

#### Robust infrastructure and support

It is vital to invest in high-quality technical infrastructure and provide ongoing maintenance and support to prevent and address technical issues promptly.

#### Standardized protocols for integration

As it stands right now, all major CSP like AWS, Azure by Microsoft, GCP are working to adapt their products to the AI era. Undeniably, we will see more actions to develop and adopt standards that facilitate seamless interoperability between AI applications and existing healthcare systems.

## Economic and workforce implications

As AI and ML algorithms decrease the time for processing mundane administrative tasks significantly, wide adoption of this technology will inevitably lead to shifts in the workforce.

### Risks:

#### Job displacement Â

Automation of certain tasks may lead to job losses or shifts in workforce requirements within the healthcare sector.

#### Economic disparities

High costs associated with implementing advanced AI technologies may widen the gap between well-funded and under-resourced healthcare facilities.

### Mitigation strategies: Â

#### Reskilling and upskilling programs for AI engineers in healthcare

Companies will provide training opportunities for healthcare workers to adapt to new roles and responsibilities that emerge alongside AI integration.

#### Equitable access initiatives

Global, federal, and state healthcare institutions should aim to develop funding models and policies that support the adoption of AI technologies across diverse healthcare settings, including those in low-resource areas.

#### Collaborative human-AI models

Both governmental and commercial bodies in the healthcare industry can reduce the risks of negative AI impact on the workforce by emphasizing models where AI augments human capabilities, leading to enhanced job satisfaction and productivity rather than replacement.

The CAIO of General Electric's HealthCare, for example, recognizes the value of AI as the facilitator of the operational and administrative processes:

## Maximizing AI's potential in healthcare through risk mitigation

While the potential of AI in healthcare is vast, from improving diagnostic accuracy to optimizing treatment plans, its implementation must be approached with care. Ensuring data privacy, reducing algorithmic bias, and maintaining transparency are critical steps in minimizing risks associated with AI. Â

A meticulous and well-regulated approach, combined with ongoing collaboration between technologists, healthcare professionals, and policymakers, will be essential to harness AI's full potential while safeguarding patient welfare and maintaining trust in the healthcare system.

Artificial and augmented intelligence: Risk management considerations for healthcare
====================================================================================

By [Joan M. Porcaro](https://www.wtwco.com/en-us/insights/all-insights#sort=%40fdate13762%20descending&f:@authors=[Joan%20M.%20Porcaro]) | October 11, 2023

A Leader’s Guide to Evaluating New Technology

[This guide](https://www.wtwco.com/-/media/wtw/insights/2023/10/healthcare--ai-and-technology-checklist.pdf?modified=20231005122920) serves as a tool for leadership to utilize when evaluating product and device acquisition.

Following the news, it's evident that healthcare professionals are keenly interested and engaged in discussions surrounding artificial intelligence (AI). The rapid development of AI applications is transforming patient-facing services, including diagnostics and predictive analytics for enhancing prevention and treatment strategies. As the surge of new applications continues, risk management professionals are increasingly taking notice.

#### Background: Navigating the evolution of AI

Taking a moment to reflect, AI is not a recent invention. Mathematician Alan Turing published the first paper on AI benefits in [1950](https://courses.cs.washington.edu/courses/csep590/06au/projects/history-ai.pdf). While the concept isn't new, the intrigue lies in the evolving applications for patients and providers. The potential applications of AI in various facets of life have grown exponentially.

Keeping up with the definitions for computer and robotic applications has become somewhat frenetic as well. For the purposes of this article, let’s review the language of AI.

#### What is artificial intelligence (AI)?

While everyone’s definition of AI is different depending on who you ask, generally speaking, AI is a broad branch of computer science concerned with creating systems, applications, and machines capable of performing tasks too complex for humans. It achieves this by processing and analyzing data, enabling it to understand and learn from past data points through specially designed [AI algorithms](https://www.tableau.com/data-insights/ai/algorithms).

Despite the hype and fear surrounding the term "artificial intelligence," it is already employed globally for tasks ranging from mundane to incredible. Some [common examples](https://www.iotforall.com/8-helpful-everyday-examples-of-artificial-intelligence) of AI include smart assistants like Alexa and Siri, social media monitoring, face recognition, smartphones, search engines like Google, and much more.

#### What are predictive analytics?

[Predictive analytics](https://www.tableau.com/learn/articles/what-is-predictive-analytics), a common tool in data science, interprets historical data to make informed predictions about the future. It employs techniques such as data mining, modeling, machine learning and statistics, aiding in identifying upcoming risks and opportunities for organizations. Examples of predictive analytics in action includes weather forecasting, Amazon’s recommendations for purchase and similar items, modeling of flu trends and insurance risk assessments.

While AI and predictive analytics overlap, the most significant difference lies in autonomy. AI can be autonomous and learn independently, whereas predictive analytics often requires human interaction to help query data, identify trends, and test assumptions.

#### Machine learning (ML)

AI and ML [overlap considerably](https://www.tableau.com/learn/articles/predictive-analytics-vs-machine-learning), with ML being a subset of AI. However, key differences exist, beyond just the fact that AI is a broader term than ML. AI aims to create computer systems imitating the human brain, focusing on broad and complex problems. In contrast, ML is more task-focused, training machines to perform specific tasks and learn in the process. AI tends to focus on solving broad and complex problems, whereas ML focuses on streamlining a certain task to maximize performance.

[Unlike predictive analytics](https://www.tableau.com/learn/articles/predictive-analytics-vs-machine-learning), ML can be autonomous and has broader applications beyond predicting data, including error detection, pattern recognition, and more. Predictive analytics can use ML to achieve its goal of predicting data, but that’s not the only technique it uses.

#### Benefits: What can AI do?

Predictive analytics is a core function of AI, rapidly analyzing large volumes of data and classifying data points. Machines can learn from experience and can be trained to accomplish specific tasks. Examples of AI applications include predictive analytics, clinical pathway decision-making, wearable tech, and off-site or home-based patient monitoring. AI can enhance efficiency, support workforce shortages, provide accurate work product and reduce training costs.

#### Addressing workforce shortages with workflow automation and AI

Radiology departments [increase productivity with healthcare technology](https://www.philips.com/a-w/about/news/archive/features/2022/20221124-10-real-world-examples-of-ai-in-healthcare.html) that leverages AI to enable faster scan times with higher resolution in imaging modalities like MR, even with patients who are in pain or struggle to hold their breath during an exam. As a result, radiology departments can scan more patients in a day while supporting diagnostic confidence and improving the patient experience at the same time.

#### Risks: A cautionary tale

The [use of AI](https://www.healthcareitnews.com/news/emea/who-warns-about-risks-ai-healthcare) in clinical diagnostics and monitoring carries both risks and benefits. Predictive analytics can assist in identifying potential health issues, yet unknown risks and awareness of assumptions can emerge with the adoption of new technology over time. Many remain optimistic that large language “generative artificial intelligence” models will improve healthcare. However, this isn’t the first time that using algorithms to make recommendations has gone awry.

#### Good news

AI can manage repetitive tasks, increase efficiency while reducing error rates for work processes and potentially reduce caregiver burnout by handling administrative tasks that burden providers in current healthcare settings. The American Medical Association (AMA) [reports that 20 hours or more per week](https://www.ama-assn.org/practice-management/sustainability/do-you-spend-more-time-administrative-tasks-your-peers) are spent on administrative tasks, and AI could alleviate this burden.

Sacramento, Calif.-based [Sutter Health](https://www.beckershospitalreview.com/innovation/how-far-is-too-far-for-ai-in-healthcare.html), for instance, uses augmented intelligence to redirect 20% of patient portal messages away from physicians to a more appropriate care-team member and give personalized, anticipatory advice to expectant mothers, leading to a 15% drop in in-basket messages there.

From the staff perspective, digital and AI solutions may offer a way to alleviate some of the load on the care team while also providing training tools that are cutting edge.

#### Not ready for prime time

In a demonstration conducted by UNC Health, another AI format, ChatGPT was used to offer [medical advice](https://www.beckershospitalreview.com/innovation/how-far-is-too-far-for-ai-in-healthcare.html). ChatGPT was given information that included a patient’s health history and then asked how the patient should be treated. While the results were spot on to how the human doctor proposed to treat the patient, the use of ChatGPT for medical diagnosis has created some controversy and concerns linger regarding inaccuracies and “[made-up](https://www.beckershospitalreview.com/innovation/that-is-exactly-how-we-treated-the-patient-chatgpt-updates-medical-expertise-surprises-physicians.html)” information in similar scenarios.

There are limitations and risks to these delivery processes and it’s imperative that the healthcare professional understand what AI can, and cannot, do. Due diligence is needed, including the following areas:

*   **Biased decision making**: Although there are [many opportunities](https://www.healthcareitnews.com/news/emea/who-warns-about-risks-ai-healthcare) for AI, a report from the World Health Organization points out associated challenges and risks, including unethical collection and use of health data, biases encoded in algorithms, as well as risks to patient safety, cybersecurity and the environment.
*   **Socioeconomic inequality**: Algorithms may create an opportunity for abuses (think deepfakes), such as sparking concerns for job loss because of automation. 
*   **Privacy violations**: [Privacy](https://builtin.com/artificial-intelligence/risks-of-artificial-intelligence) may not be assured for virtual care or AI, and personal health information may be at risk of breach.
*   **Available historical data**: AI requires [massive data sets](https://healthitanalytics.com/news/arguing-the-pros-and-cons-of-artificial-intelligence-in-healthcare) in order to “learn,” thus requiring volumes of patient health information for the machine learning to take place. With this level of “machine” training, data output validation takes place. AI and machine learning foster the [creation](https://ldi.upenn.edu/our-work/research-updates/artificial-intelligence-and-medical-liability-system-reforms/) of algorithms. With continued advancement of this technology, some groundbreaking applications offer a new way to monitor risks — the so-called ‘[black box algorithm](https://jolt.law.harvard.edu/assets/articlePDFs/v31/The-Artificial-Intelligence-Black-Box-and-the-Failure-of-Intent-and-Causation-Yavar-Bathaee.pdf).’ These algorithms are constantly updating and learning based on data inputs — but the exact identity and weighting of variables cannot be determined as they constantly evolve.
*   **Learning curve**: Ensure that staff understand the limitations of AI.
*   **Human factors**: However, at issue relative to risks and benefits is the possibility that AI may not be able to interpret all human nuances, which could result in biases, lapses and unintended consequences in care. While AI can certainly enhance the capabilities of healthcare providers, it should never replace them entirely.
*   **Ethical issues and dilemmas**: Ethical concerns are justified when [false](https://builtin.com/artificial-intelligence/risks-of-artificial-intelligence) information is pushed out. Another issue to consider: Do people want early warning of insipient disease?

#### Regulations

Currently, AI regulations are absent in the United States, but changes are anticipated. The White House's "Blueprint for an AI Bill of Rights" outlines principles guiding the design and implementation of automated systems, emphasizing safety, non-discrimination

SUMMARY:
Introduction Artificial intelligence (AI) is rapidly entering health care and serving major roles, from automating drudgery and routine tasks in medical practice to managing patients and medical resources. As developers create AI systems to take on these tasks, several risks and challenges emerge, including the risk of injuries to patients from AI system errors, the risk to patient privacy of data acquisition and AI inference, and more. Potential solutions are complex but involve investment in infrastructure for high-quality, representative data; collaborative oversight by both the Food and Drug Administration and other health-care actors; and changes to medical education that will prepare providers for shifting roles in an evolving system. The most obvious risk is that AI systems will sometimes be wrong, and that patient injury or other health-care problems may result.

Introduction
------------

Artificial intelligence (AI) is rapidly entering health care and serving major roles, from automating drudgery and routine tasks in medical practice to managing patients and medical resources. As developers create AI systems to take on these tasks, several risks and challenges emerge, including the risk of injuries to patients from AI system errors, the risk to patient privacy of data acquisition and AI inference, and more. Potential solutions are complex but involve investment in infrastructure for high-quality, representative data; collaborative oversight by both the Food and Drug Administration and other health-care actors; and changes to medical education that will prepare providers for shifting roles in an evolving system.
